Our junior suite was exquisite with a large king size bed with wonderful linen sheets which looked brand new. The room had padded fabric brocard walls, a large walk-in closet, sitting area and a huge white marble bathroom (large jacuzzi tub, dual sinks and dual water-fall showers which were refreshing!). We couldn't help but to feel as if we were some distant relatives of the d'Medici family. Upon checking into our room, there was a large tray of chocolate dipped strawberries and a bottle of Prosecco. I would estimate that the room was approximately 500 or so square feet, which I think in Venice is probably pretty large. Not much of a view out of the windows other than what looked to be a utility alley of some sort although being on the fifth floor we really didn't mind (a nice canal or city view would have been nice though). Excellent hotel in general for honeymooners as it is tucked down a sleepy and quiet side street literally a block from San Marco (if you can believe that) which provides a lot of quiet and privacy. I bet a thousand people a day walk right past the street not even realizing that a 5 star hotel is a few feet away. Lounge is equally wonderful with a nice relaxed feel. Breakfast in the morning had pretty much everything you can think of from breads, fruits, eggs, salmon, etc. served in a room fit for royalty. We ate at the Canova restaurant for dinner one night which we thought was very good (the grappa cart for your after-dinner digestif is always a nice touch!). I especially liked the votive candles that they placed around the lobby and on the huge marble staircase at night which provided good ambience and set a very romantic tone. Also liked that you had to leave your key at the front desk when leaving the hotel which reminds me of old-world style hotels (the key fob looks like a bell and is so large and heavy you wouldn't want to carry it around anyways). Front desk personnel were very helpful and unintrusive. Cable internet access is free (as it should be - see my review of the Villa d'Este in Cernobbio/Como which wasn't at $1000 a night) and there was never a problem getting on the one computer that they have just off of the lobby. Fresh fruit and prosecco provided for guests in the lobby daily (nice touch!). In general, first-class experience and would definitely return to this hotel again.

Reviews.Title: “Loved Venice, just "in like" with the Luna Baglioni”
Reviews.Author: gbcfb
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Luna Baglioni at tthe tail end of a European Incentive Trip. This was our first visit to Europe. We were given an impromptu tour of the Grand Canal on our way to the Baglioni and it was a treat for us to arrive at the doorstep of our hotel by water taxi. The hotel was very prompt with our check-in process. We were pre-registered and were given our huge key and shown our room in quick order. The Luna has not gone the way of the electronic locks and still have the old fashioned room key. The key is on a massive key chain (a large gold tassel) which is to be turned into the front desk each time you leave the hotel (pick up on the way in). Very quaint. The lobby of the hotel is beautiful, marble floors, gleaming wooden staircase, antique (but roped-off) furniture. What was a little odd was the lighting. It was dim and a little on the gloomy side...as if they needed to somehow hide the interior with bad lighting. We were scheuled to have a "deluxe" accomodation level room. I've seen the pictures on the website of the various rooms available at the Luna and I must say that I was disappointed by my room - Room #102. We had a fairly spacious room with a king bed. I had the impression that most of the rooms had the romantic canopied beds and views of the water. Instead I got a comfortable bed sans canopy overlooking the alley between the hotel and an arcade of shops. My husband is not the type to complain and didn't want to ask about another room. So room #102 was our home for our two day stay. Like I said, the room was really quite spacious. But like the lighting, there was something a little off. I couldn't decide if the decor was "shabby chic" or just plain shabby. Faded walls, faded carpet. Very antique feel. The lights in the room were controled by switches located next to the bed (overhead, side light and privacy button). I'm pretty sure that our "private" light was not working because we kept getting knocks by the staff. There is a television in the room. Not exactly state of the art but it worked. It was a little on the smallish size (probably a 20' screen) and it was hard to figure out how to work the remote. We only watched CNN during our first couple of hours and spent most of our waking hours exploring the city. The was some sort of temperature control in the room. However, like the TV remote, we could never quite figure it out. We got a lot of "fan" action but no real cool air. It does get muggy and with our window just one story up from the street, we didn't feel good about opening the window for air during the day because of the noise from the foot traffic below. The bathroom was also pretty big. With a combination tub/shower and double sinks. The hair dryer was not exactly the most powerful of things, the one instance where you probably should bring your own (with the adapter). They don't have a shower curtain but use intead a half glass wall. I somehow managed to dislogde the half wall (it moves on a hinge) and the water leaked onto the floor. I know that I'm not the first because the carpet right outside the bathroom door had water damage. There was internet access which was extremely necessary for my workaholic husband. The hotel has not set up in-room access. Not the most convenient as you had to use the hotel's set up downstairs next to the coatroom. Pretty slow connection but at least you do have access. We had breakfast included in the room package. We're not really breakfast people, but the spread was as would be expected (some hot-eggs, bacon) more cold (cereal, fruit, pastries) with the ability to order ala carte from the breakfast menu. The breakfast room was quite a sight to see. The whole "salon" feel was overwhelming. I felt like I needed a wig and a corset. Beautiful ceiling and walls. The location of the hotel was perfecct for us. Really close (1/4 of a block) to St Mark's Square and next to the water bus stop for St Mark's. Lots of activity in the area for a first time Venice visitor - the doge palace, the basilica, the bridge of sighs, multiple souvenir vendors, feeding the pidgeons, gondola stands (which are just like starbuck - seemingly always around the corner), restaurants abound between the Square and the Rialto Bridge. We managed to get tickets for the Secret Itinerary Tour at the Doge Palace which was a lot of fun. It was the only chance we had to go inside one of the historic buildings. The lines were out the door for the basilica and the campanile. We fed the pigeons, saw all three bridges, took the gondola ride and paid way too much for it. Took pictures, bought glass and art and took enough pictures that even my 1 gig was not enough. Our whole goal was to just get lost in Venice. Share a romantic gondola ride, enjoy the sights and feel of this beautiful city. We would love to come back and bring our children to Venice. And despite the somewhat gloominess of the hotel, the location can't be beat and we would return.

Reviews.Title: “First class, well-managed hotel”
Reviews.Author: FirstBruno
Reviews.Content: We booked a junior suite with a view of the Lagoon. It was large, very well furnished and well-kept. The marble bathroom, which also had a Lagoon view, had two sinks and plenty of room. For the first time in recent years, in any hotel anywhere, we did not have to ask for extra clothes hangers. A small point, but it shows attention to detail and the requirements of the sort of people who stay there. Concierge service was excellent. The staff were better than Michelin and much better than the London Financial Times at recommending places to eat The breakfast was good but expensive (Euro 25 each). Dinner in the restaurant was adequate but not outstanding. The Luna is one of the best located hotels in Venice, only a few yards from St Mark's Square and literally on top of or beside some of the best shops. It is therefore not far from some excellent restaurants. Be prepared however for a ten-minute walk to the best (the concierges will tell you 15 minutes, but obviously they don't want any comeback if you are slow walkers. If necessary, take a water bus!). A word on prices in Venice. They are very high but the market can obviously bear them. In the case of the Luna Baglioni, what was provided was in accordance with the price: we paid top whack for the best.

Reviews.Title: “Plesantly Surprised....”
Reviews.Author: Cissy
Reviews.Content: I recently returned from a visit to Italy, Venice being one of the cities. I had decided early on in the planning stages of my trip to stay at the Luna Baglioni while in Venice. I was a bit skeptical in staying in the heart of everything but decided none the less that the Baglioni would my choice. Upon arriving via private water taxi (the hotel arranged for my transfer from the terminal to the private taxi to take me to the hotel) my first eyeview was lovely and charming to say the least. Arriving early Sunday morning my room was not ready as they had been full from the previous evening (I was booked for a deluxe room and the lesser category was available - I preferred to wait for my room) I decided to take a walk and get a coffee. Unfortunatetly when I returned from my coffee my room was still not ready so I decided to freshen up and venture out for lunch (Alla Madonna - near the Rialto bridge was wonderful) and when I returned back to the hotel after lunch my room was ready - and it was simply gorgeous. Large, decorated lovely, large bathroom, spotless and quiet. I was so happy that I decided to wait and not take the lesser category room. One of the most delightful little extras that the Baglioni does is at night when you return from dinner to your room there are candles lit in the bathroom and sleeping area. I found the concierge staff to be quite helpful and very friendly with some good restaurant recommendations (I did have a list of my own which we would discuss). One very valid and valued recommendation was to visit the Doges Palace late in the day after about 4:30pm - you will be amazed as there is no que and you can just walk right in. The staff had also pre-arranged a couple of excursions for me which were handled quite efficiently (a must is a private water taxi to the island of Torcello to lunch at Locando Cipriani which was wonderful.) Breakfast every morning was perfect - from choices to service . I was very pleasantly surprised by the hotels restaurant - it was excellent - from service to food. I was a bit hesitant to dine at the hotel but decided due to the heavy rain one evening to dine in the hotel restaurant - I was very glad I did. Excellent food choices, great wines, and staff that was top - friendly and professional - a great dining experience. Lastly, I found the location of the hotel to be tops. While right in the heart of the square - it is off to the side - on the canal - quiet - perfect for escaping the masses of people yet close enough to everything. The Luna Baglioni was a wonderful experience and I will most certainly stay there again when I return to Venice.

Reviews.Title: “well worth the trip”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We had a wonderful time at this hotel. It was off the beaten path where we could watch the gondolas come and go, yet just a few short steps from St. Mark's square. The staff was attentive and professional. In addition, without our asking, they upgraded us to a junior suite at no extra charge. If you want a quiet hotel that is still in the middle of everything, I highly suggest you try the Baglioni.

Reviews.Title: “Great location!!”
Reviews.Author: stacvic
Reviews.Content: Got a great deal on the hotel making it about 100 pounds a night. Great Breakfast, great location! Rooms a little small but clean and great venician decor.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely”
Reviews.Author: FlossieBoo
Reviews.Content: What more can we say, Fabulous!! Lovely Service, Good location, Gorgeous room, Perfect!!! Would love to come again as we were looked after so well.

Reviews.Title: “Very Nice!”
Reviews.Author: DBSEA
Reviews.Content: We recently stayed at the Baglioni for 2 nights while in Venice. We found the hotel to be quite nice for the $$ we spent. The location was perfect as we wanted to be walking distance to St. Marks Square. The breakfast buffet was delicious! The breakfast room is very spacious and elegant. They had a nice variety of choices and the food was good. The breakfast was also included in our room rate, so the value was there for us. Our room was "okay" not that special, but we hardley spent any time in it, so it didn't really matter. The front desk staff was very nice and helpful. We LOVED Venice and hope to go back in the near future!

Reviews.Title: “Truly one of the Best!”
Reviews.Author: MarylandSpringTravel
Reviews.Content: Just returned from several days in Venice. The Luna Baglione Hotel was worth every cent. We arrived amidst a downpour and it was great to walk a few yards from the Vallaresso vaporetto to the Hotel entrance. The staff was incredibly attentive, the room generously proportioned and the attention to detail superb. A sumptuous breakfast is served in a magnificent room by the friendliest staff we encountered in any of the comparable hotels we visited during our trip. We needed a 4:30am water taxi and the Concierge handled all details perfectly. It has free Internet access from a private workstation, a rarity in Italy. The Hotel is a few steps from St. Mark's square making it easy to return midday if needed. Highly recommend two restaurants which are also in Rick Steve's book: Osteria Enoteca San Marco, a couple of blocks from the Luna, and Trattoria da Remigio, a few blocks further past the Rio de Greci. Reservations probably required but both worth the effort. Stay away from Trattoria De Forni; we ended up there the night we arrived and do NOT recommend it.

Reviews.Title: “The gleaming but dismal Luna”
Reviews.Author: Rektikano
Reviews.Content: There is something depressing about this hotel. The staff cannot be faulted: they are immaculately turned out and immaculately behaved. Attentive. Courteous. Perfect. Everything is polished: marble, wood, glass. But it has the same slightly ersatz feeling about it as the Baglioni Hotel in London: as if the whole thing has been put together by someone who has heard what a 5 star hotel is meant to be like, but never seen one. Fake antique chairs abound, mixed in with a few genuine (roped-off) ones. The corridors are dismal to the point of suicidal: dimly lit, not in a romantic way, but rather in a "has there been a power cut and is this the emergency lighting?" way. The carpets have a dingy, worn-out feeling to them, and the room decor teeters on the fine line between faded Venetian flair and Wild West bordello. The hotel is well located in terms of access to San Marco, but in terms of backstreets you really are in the middle of the slightly-trashed-by-tourism side to Venice, along with the identikit designer boutiques you can see everywhere from Tokyo to LA. Adequate, but I won't be going back.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel”
Reviews.Author: moldavian
Reviews.Content: Wow! What a terrific hotel! The staff were very friendly and accommodating and the service was excellent. The rooms were nice but a bit small; however, the bathroom was generous and well appointed. The location of the hotel is perfect for its proximity to the major tourist attractions. San marco is right next door! There are quite a few other hotels within easy reach of San marco, but Luna Baglioni is the only one adjacent to a vaporetto stop. as far as we could tell, it is also the only hotel with direct water access to the Grand Canal. Take a water taxi from the airport to the hotel as it is worth the price for door-to-door service. Ask the driver to take you through the Grand Canal on your way as it takes just as long as the direct route to the hotel and offers an incredible grand entrance into the city. The price for the private taxi service from the hotel is 90 Euro. We are so glad that we did this as it saved over an hour; although, catching the bus is easy as you only have to transfer once in Venice. If you have a lot of luggage then you may want to refrain from taking the bus as it was always completely packed and standing room only. From the airport you have to walk about 1,000 feet to the dock; it took us ten minutes to walk with large suitcases. You will not have to wait for a taxi - there will be plenty waiting. Finally, the food. BEWARE!!!! There are many restaurants that are simply tourist traps. The food was terrible and the service even worse. They always tried to rush you through your meal so that the next party could be seated in your place. The best restaurants were the establishments that were recommended to us by the hotel or other travelers. At these locations everything was perfect! So, get advise before blindly choosing a restaurant. Also, don't forget about the high cost of food and drinks in Venice. At restaurants you will pay $9-10 USD for a bottle of water or soda. At bars you will pay about $12-15 for a mixed drink or glass of wine. It's outrageous! But, you only get to go once right? Well, maybe more if you are fortunate. overall, the luna Baglioni is a great luxury hotel with the perfect location. Note: If you must leave the hotel early in the morning to catch a flight don't worry about getting to the airport 2 hours ahead of time. 45-60 minutes will do. The airport is small and not too busy in the morning. Also, water taxi's run all night and we had no problem booking a taxi at 5 in the morning. The bus to the airport runs early as well (I'm not sure of the hours but we saw people standing in the cold with their luggage waiting for it).

Reviews.Title: “Perfect Location”
Reviews.Author: WharfTrader
Reviews.Content: thought this was a great hotel - fantastic location right by san marco - moments from the vaporetto stop, and harry's bar is on the corner - got a great deal for the time of year so was nervous of the room - but we got a great one - no view from the room but hardly in it as there is plenty to see in venice! - the decor was a bit chintzy, but comfy - bathroom a good size - staff were professional - didn't eat there but the bar looked nice - excellent base for seeing the city - would recommend getting the bus to piazzale roma and then a vaporetto down the canal when you get there - great way to see the city - and very easy to get around with a good map and once you know where san marco and the rialto are - would recommend this hotel if you can get a good deal

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Baglioni”
Reviews.Author: carol30
Reviews.Content: My husband and I have just got back from 3 fantastic nights at the Luna Baglioni. We had booked a superior room but on arrival were upgraded for free to a junior suite which was gorgeous, beautiful Venetian furnishings, Murano chandeliers, marble bathroom with a Jacuzzi bath, plasma TV. It was on the first floor overlooking a Calle so didnâ€™t have a view but it was very quiet. Each evening while we were out a maid would come into our room to turn the bed down but also light candles by the bed and place slippers out for you. My only negative point about the room was that there wasnâ€™t any tea or coffee making facilities. We ate in the Canova restaurant the first night which was expensive (but not so bad considering what you pay elsewhere for less). The food was lovely and the service was better than we have ever had anywhere in the world. The best of the meals we had in our 3 days. Breakfast is 25 euros each which we decided was not worth it so instead choose to grab a coffee and pastry when we were out. The reception staff were generally pleasant, although the concierge was not the most happiest of people, but found them efficient, polite and useful. The hotel is in a fantastic location, just meters away from the San Marco / Vallaresso vaporetti stop so it is easy to get around the island and from the bus/train station. Harryâ€™s bar is also at the end of the street but donâ€™t bother to go there as it was the biggest waste of money / let down we had during our stay in Venice. We canâ€™t comment on what the normal rooms are like but we loved the Luna and would highly recommend it.

Reviews.Title: “Best of everything in Venice @ the Luna!”
Reviews.Author: ceeceerose
Reviews.Content: There is nothing negative I can say about this hotel. The service...the location...the quality was all EXTREMELY superior. From the bus from the train station, all it takes to get to this treasure is a half block walk. On one end of the street there is the Grand Canal and on the other end, St. Mark's Square. St. Mark's is right in the heart of the city, so stopping by the hotel during the day to rest or freshen up was not out of the way at all. Not overly stuffy...this one is just right for the perfect stay in this beautiful city.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Baglioni”
Reviews.Author: Nicknack43
Reviews.Content: A real find in Venice. Accommodations, ambience and location were excellent. Most of the staff were welcoming and friendly however, the front desk staff seemed annoyed at questions or requests for directions, not very friendly. We were unexpectedly upgraded to a suite - magnificent room decor and a stunning view.

Reviews.Title: “you simply can't beat the location...”
Reviews.Author: expatimmexico
Reviews.Content: You simply can not get closer to the st.marcos square, only a few steps away. Although quite expensive (we paid $370), it fullfills your expectations of a romantic hotel in venice. Our rooms were very small, but as luxurious as it gets and the view from the balcony was wonderful (see my posted pictures). I doubt that anyone choosing this hotel will be disappointed with either their rooms or the food and service of the restaurant and cafe. Be aware that the check in and check out times are stricktly enforced though (14:00 and 12:00)...

Reviews.Title: “Luxury at the Luna”
Reviews.Author: Tuckers_Travels
Reviews.Content: My wife and I booked this hotel off of luxury link travel auction website and it certainly lived up to our expectations. We notified them that we were going to arrive early since we were on the morning flight into Venice. When we arrived at the hotel, they had our room ready for us and we were able to shower and begin our adventures in Venice. The breakfast buffet is huge and full of breads, meats, cheeses, lots of fresh fruit and juices. They also serve scrambled eggs (might have been from a mix though) and bacon. The breakfast room itself is like dining in an 18th century ballroom. The maitre d' and her staff were very accomodating. Our room was large, especially by European standards with plenty of closet space. The bathroom was double sink and here is the one drawback. The shower and tub were combined with only a small glass half door (typical in many European shower/tub combos). As a result, inexperienced bathers would likely get some water splashing around the bathroom and feel like you had to do your business in a more confined area. The hotel is very conveniently located near the St. Mark's ACTV stop and the square itself. Despite being located in such a busy area, the hotel and room were very quiet which was nice when you are trying to escape the crowds. Dinner at the restaurant was excellent and the service quite good. The concierge staff is helpful and can book concerts and dinner reservations. As for Venice itself, be prepared to pay a fortune to eat. The cheapest restaurants are still expensive and you should expect to pay around 50-70 EUR per person to eat at a decent establishment. It's all part of the island economy here. For transportation from the airport, we recommend buying the Alilaguna Oro (Gold) line ticket for 25EUR per person. We were actually transported by taxi with one other couple directly to Saint Marks. Don't miss the Peggy Guggenheim museum if you like modern art, it was one of the highlights of our trip. Also, try to take in a concert at one of the smaller venues, it was a treat. We saw Interpreti Veneziani's rendition of Vivaldi's Quattro Staggione. One final suggestion, we purchased the Red Map from Barnes and Noble prior to the trip and it was invaluable. Very easy to understand and portable. Enjoy your trip.

Reviews.Title: “Loved Luna Baglioni”
Reviews.Author: Frang
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Luna Baglioni Sept. 17th for 3 days. It is a wonderful, clean, and beautifully appointed hotel. I had booked a Jr. Suite and was given a upgrade to a suite. The room was outstanding. We had a large living room area with a plasma TV, huge bedroom with plasma TV, and huge bathroom, double sinks, large, large shower and separate bathtub. We had a view of the Canal. This hotel is perfectly located, a few steps from San Marco Square, but far enough to be away from the noise. Originally, we wanted to stay at the Danielli, but glad we didn't. We visited the Danielli and there was so much hustle and bustle in the hotel lobby with just people stopping in to have a peak. The front desk staff were polite, and the dinner in the dining room was excellent. It was so good we ate there twice. I would recommend this hotel very highly. When I go back to Venice this is the place I would stay again.

Reviews.Title: “Luna Baglioni is a great place to stay in Venice”
Reviews.Author: londonvisi2r
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Luna Baglioni for three nights in September, 2005. As has been noted by other reviewers, the location is absolutely perfect -- just steps from St. Mark's Square -- yet very quiet at night. Our room was lovely and clean -- very comfortable bed -- perfectly fine bathroom with shower -- good airconditioning. Unfortunately, there was no view at all, so anyone booking here should request a view. The staff were friendly and competent. Also, the private boat dock feature cannot be overemphasized. Venice, with all its steps, is not a great place to be dragging your luggage around; but the Luna Baglioni's private dock allowed your luggage to be brought within 10 feet of the door. Staying here was a real plus in a completely unique and beautiful city -- everyone should visit it!!

Reviews.Title: “Brilliant Baglioni”
Reviews.Author: Graham B
Reviews.Content: We had a superb weekend at the Baglioni celebrating our 25th wedding anniversary. Our junior suite was upgraded to probably the best suite in the hotel complete with roof terrace. Sparkling wine and home made chocolates in the room and champagne to drink whilst we checked in. The hotel is adjacent to San Marco square and similarly close to the Grand Canal making sight seeing very accessible. Despite being in the centre of Venice the hotel is surprising peaceful and quiet. We had one evening meal in the hotel restaurant - top class service and food and not too expensive. We also ate at al Covo (recommended in a number of guides) but I would only describe it as average. Breakfasts were served in a wonderful salon, again super service and excellent food. The hotel is well worth it for a special ocasion or luxury break - top marks!

Reviews.Title: “Hotel Luna Baglioni - You Will Not Be Disappointed”
Reviews.Author: clay304399
Reviews.Content: My wife and i stayed at the hotel Luna Baglioni during july 2005. What a fantastic hotel. We found out that it is the oldest hotel in venice,founded by the knights templars. On arrival at the airport,we took a short walk to the taxi bay where we caught our own private boat which took us straight to the hotels own gondola booth. Beware it did cost 70 euro! But well worth it. We caught the public water taxi on the way back to the airport which took over an hour. The hotel is situated literally 20m from St Marks Sqaure. We booked a suite which was full of old antiques,spar bath,and the view from the room was breathtaking. The staff were very helpful,and dining was excellent,however was somewhat expensive for what it was. There are cheaper options down the narrow alleyways where you can get great italian food at a good price. Gondola rides are not cheap,however it must be done. There is so much to see in venice that our 2 day break was not enough to get around it all. A good bit of advice however,start your sightseeing early, around 0830 hrs as the tourists start to arrive at 0900 hrs and the queues do get long. The hotel is to die for,the venice experience is also what you dream it would be. However costly it seems,push the boat out you never know when it will sink!

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel, fantastic location”
Reviews.Author: Oxford_grrl
Reviews.Content: We visited the Luna Baglioni for two nights in June 2005 and thought it was a real find. Twenty paces from St Mark's Square, thirty from a vaparetto stop - you can't do better for location for your first visit to Venice. We stayed in a corner room at the back and top of the hotel, overlooking the exclusive shops and the tops of neighbouring buildings but there was no street noise, and the sound of bells from the local churches (generally after 8 in the morning) were charming not intrusive. The air-conned room and bathroom were spacious and spotlessly clean; both very well decorated with expensive furnishings. The bed was large and firm, with high thread count, expensive linens. The end of the toilet roll was perfectly folded and stuck down with a tiny crested sticker after the twice-daily housekeeping visits!! Lovely finishing touches also included crystal chandeliers, slippers and soft mats for the bedsides. The foyer and other areas of the hotel were beautiful and quiet. At night, candles were placed on the stairs leading from reception, a lovely sight to greet you on your return from a long day. Staff were pleasant and efficient at all times, spoke English very well and were happy to store bags on our final day in a secure room. We booked via the excellent website with no problem and received some lovely emails for confirmation. There was some confusion at the end of our stay where apparently the bill still had to be settled despite prebooking with a credit card. This was fine, however. Harry's Bar is on the same block - if you can afford it, pay 20 Euros for a small glass of Bellini at one of the tables (cheaper at the bar, but you'll be pursuaded to sit down!), and then amble over to St Mark's for a cafe latte at Florian. That will blow your budget for the day! With two stops close to the hotel, use the vaparettos (get a 3 day pass) to get around Venice and the waterbus to get to and from the airport (although the bus is cheaper and faster). We didn't eat at the hotel, so cannot comment on breakfast. The restaurant looked lovely but empty - you might get a voucher for a free bottle of wine in your room. Based on our stay at the Luna, we will definitely be visiting other hotels in the Baglioni chain, starting with Rome next!

Reviews.Title: “Poor service by grumpy staff”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Arrived at midday to be told we could not check in until 2pm which was fair enough. After a spot of lunch we returned at 1.45pm to be told that the room would be ready about 2.30. All we wanted to do was freshen up before doing some sight seeing. We finally got our room at 3.30pm with our luggage finding its way to us some 3 hours later at 6.30!!!! Lots of excuses but not one apology. As a member of the Leading Hotels of the World they are supposed to provide luxurious accomodation and SERVICE. As we were only in Venice for two nights this got the trip off to a bad start and although we did manage to see some of Venice, ride on the gondola and go to the opera the weekend was tainted by this bad start. Shame on you Baglioni and remember manners cost nothing. I would return to Venice but not to the Baglioni even if it was free.

Reviews.Title: “the best hotel in venice”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed 2 nights at the luna. I'm glad I cancelled the Danielli on time!!. this is the typical elegant european hotel with great service, great bathrooms, plasma tv and spacecious rooms.

Reviews.Title: “A Memorable Experience!!!”
Reviews.Author: AJD77
Reviews.Content: How fortunate we were to heed our good friends advice and spend 3 wonderful days at the Luna. Our room overlooking the Grand Canal was elegantly furnished and could not have been more comfortable. The service was Five Star!!! Anxiously awaiting a revisit. Antonio and Giovanna, CT

Reviews.Title: “A little piece of heaven”
Reviews.Author: Baby74
Reviews.Content: My husband and I found this hotel to be in a great location to take advantage of all that Venice has to offer. We were able to walk very easily to all of the sights that we wanted to see and the surrounding restaurants were terrific. It was nice to have some fantastic shops nearby as well. The room we had was very clean and had a nice view over one of the smaller canals. The beds were quite comfortable. The breakfast, while in a stunning room, was atrocious. We found it overpriced for what it had to offer and when we ordered scrambled eggs, they arrived cold. Not very well done for a five star hotel, I must say. Another drawback was the attitude of the concierge. We had expected this after having read previous reviews posted but when he wouldn't even call for a water taxi to take us to the train station after we had checked out it definitely left a bad taste in our mouths. Additionally, another one of the concierges would only recommend the hotel restaurant. While we would have happily eaten there, it was a gorgeous day and we had asked about outdoor restaurants, which this one was not. That said, we would stay again and recommend it to others for its location and well-appointed rooms. Make sure to check out the restaurant recommendations given by Robert-J, they were incredibly helpful and the food at the places we tried was superb.

Reviews.Title: “Didn't have to stay there to receive poor service...”
Reviews.Author: tropo
Reviews.Content: Over a month ago I made an online reservation for July, 2005, at this hotel through their website. I got a confirmation onscreen, but waited in vain for an email confirmation. I finally sent them two faxes before they replied to me that they had no record of our reservation. I now have confirmed reservations at another Venice hotel. But at least I have their fax to send to my credit card company if they try to charge my credit card for a no show.

Reviews.Title: “Loved the Luna Baglioni Hotel”
Reviews.Author: TravelerfromMexico
Reviews.Content: This hotel is beyond words. It is absolutely gorgeous and perfectly located. The rooms are beautiful and the bathrooms are excellent. My parents stayed in this same hotel more than 30 years ago and they had great things to say, so it was great staying here also. I would certainly return to this hotel and will recommend it to my friends.

Reviews.Title: “Terrible place--not worth the money!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I was very displeased with this place. For the amount of money you spend, you can get a better deal at the Hotel Saturnia. After staying in several hotels in Italy on my honeymoon, this one was by far the worst. The staff were inconsistent where they were either really agitated or just courteous when asked anything. They were never service friendly however. The beds were awful. You sank into it & not in a good way. The rooms were good sized but otherwise, I was not impressed. All in all, you are paying for location since it's around the corner to San Marcos square. So if you are staying for one night, it may work but any more than that, I highly recommend against this place.

Reviews.Title: “Great choice”
Reviews.Author: londontraveller
Reviews.Content: Stayed here as part of a group studying architecture. Mostly really delighted with this hotel. The rooms are very well equipped, mine had a lovely black marble bathroom and overlooked a tiny canal. The location is superb - a minute or two from St Marks and seconds away from a canal 'bus stop'. The breakfast room has a wonderful, over-the-top mural, all chubby cherubs and fluufy clouds. The restaurant is pretty good,although I disagree with the other poster that Venetian food is a let-down. Away from the worst tourist traps of St Marks and around the Rialto, there are wonderful restaurants to be found. My only two (very minor) criticisms of the hotel would be: the desk staff were only OK (you kind of expect more for this price) and the communal areas, recently remodelled I believe, are rather bland and 'international hotel' - a shame in Venice's oldest hotel...

Reviews.Title: “Perfect”
Reviews.Author: ronca
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed here as the first stop of our honeymoon, for four nights in April 2004. I was lucky enough to have a contact in the travel business who was able to get me a very good rate ($500 or so a night - believe me, a very good rate). We arrived by water taxi from the airport at the private dock, and from that point on the whole stay was effortless. It always seemed to us as though there were only about a dozen guests, as the same people would appear for breakfast in the sumptuous chandelier-clad dining room each and every morning. All aspects of service were prompt and efficient, professional with a friendly touch. It was quite the opposite of a standard business hotel (and I've stayed in many) because we definitely didn't feel like mere numbers at all. Two highlights for us were firstly the location (I would guess fifteen seconds walk from St. Mark's Square), yet in a quiet canal-side spot. Secondly, the beds are the most amazingly comfortable we'd ever experienced. Well, I know I only said two highlights, but the breakfast has to be mentioned as well - just about everything you could ever imagine being presented with for breakfast, and all delicous. If you are planning to stay in Venice and budget is not a problem (or to use a more cliched euphemism - you're willing to 'push the boat out'), the Luna should be your choice.
